positions.title: Three Attitudes Toward Religion
positions.content: There are fundamentally three attitudes toward religion: (1) uncritical acceptance, (2) rejection, and (3) critical/reflective acceptance.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies three basic stances one can take toward religion. Uncritical acceptance is the attitude of someone who doesn't know that non-religious views are possible (e.g., pre-modern tribesmen). Rejection is the attitude of those who examine religion scientifically and conclude it's false (e.g., Freud). Critical acceptance is the attitude of scholars like James, Otto, and Eliade who supplement scientific rationalism with firsthand knowledge of religious experience.
positions.implications: This tripartite division provides a framework for understanding different approaches to religious phenomena and suggests that neither naive acceptance nor simple rejection captures the full complexity of religious experience.

positions.title: Contemporary Fundamentalism is Reactive, Not Uncritical
positions.content: Contemporary religious fundamentalists are not genuinely 'uncritically accepting' of religion because they live in pluralistic societies and are reacting against non-religious views.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that true uncritical acceptance of religion requires not even knowing that rejection is possible. Contemporary fundamentalists choose their fundamentalism in reaction to non-fundamentalist views. They have access to contrary perspectives through books, newspapers, and websites. By contrast, pre-civilizational tribesmen held spiritual beliefs naturally, not as a defensive reaction against alternative worldviews.
positions.implications: This suggests that contemporary fundamentalism is psychologically and epistemologically distinct from pre-modern religious belief, being more a form of ideology than genuine spiritualism.

positions.title: Contemporary Atheism as Herd Mentality
positions.content: Most contemporary atheists are simply following social norms rather than reasoning independently, making their mentality similar to medieval religious believers.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes authentic rejectionism (e.g., Freud) from inauthentic rejectionism. Inauthentic rejectionists join atheist groups to fit in or gain prestige. Their beliefs are as dogmatic and emotionally-driven as medieval peasants' beliefs, even if the content is more reasonable. The brain centers mediating militant atheism are identical to those mediating religious fundamentalism.
positions.implications: This challenges the view that contemporary atheism represents rational progress, suggesting instead that for many it's merely a different form of conformity with similar psychological mechanisms as fundamentalism.

positions.title: Reductive vs. Non-Reductive Accounts of Religion
positions.content: There are both reductive (explanatory/causal) and non-reductive (phenomenological/essential) truths about religion, and the essence of religion lies in non-reductive truths.
positions.context: Kuczynski contrasts Freud's reductive approach (God represents father, religion mediates biological/social functions) with James' non-reductive approach. James doesn't deny reductive explanations but argues they're incomplete. Just as Newton's science can't be reduced to his psychological backstory, religious positions may need to be understood on their own terms even if they also admit of causal/functional explanations.
positions.implications: This suggests a methodological pluralism in studying religion where both causal-functional and phenomenological-essential approaches are necessary for complete understanding.

positions.title: Religion Requires Unshakable Conviction in Transcendence
positions.content: The essence of religious sentiment is the unshakable conviction that 'this world is not all that there is' and that psychological health requires this view.
positions.context: According to James, Otto, and Eliade's interpretation, religion essentially involves believing in something beyond the mundane world. They hold that psychologically healthy people, even self-identified agnostics and atheists, hold some variant of this view. Those who genuinely lack this view succumb to psychological morbidity.
positions.implications: This suggests that some form of belief in transcendence or 'something more' is psychologically necessary, which may be maintained even by those who explicitly reject religious labels.

positions.title: Writing as the Basis of Rationalism
positions.content: The development of writing is the foundation of rationalism, creating economies of scale and enabling the linearization of time.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that rationalism emerges with writing. The written word enables large-scale social organization ('economies of scale') and transforms temporal consciousness from circular to linear. Religion in its institutionalized form represents an early stage of rationalism, not genuine pre-literate spiritualism.
positions.implications: This provides a materialist account of the emergence of rationalist thought, linking cognitive and social changes to technological developments in communication.

positions.title: Economies of Scale Cause Time-Linearization
positions.content: Large-scale economic and social organization causes the shift from circular to linear conceptions of time characteristic of rationalism.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that as societies develop writing and create larger economic systems with 'economies of scale,' temporal consciousness shifts from the cyclical time of agricultural societies to the linear time of rational-bureaucratic societies. This transformation is fundamental to the emergence of rationalism.
positions.implications: This suggests that basic metaphysical and phenomenological categories (like temporal consciousness) have material-social bases and are not purely abstract or a priori.

positions.title: James, Otto, and Eliade Describe Animism, Not Institutional Religion
positions.content: When James, Otto, and Eliade discuss 'religion,' they are actually describing pre-civilizational animistic spiritualism, not institutional religions like Christianity or Islam.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that James, Otto, and Eliade misuse the term 'religion.' They describe a mindset where one sees rocks as monster-hearts and trees as living beings—a pre-rational, animistic spiritualism. They are not describing Christianity, Islam, or other institutional religions, which are 'complex and internally consistent behavioral codes' that merely contain 'throwbacks to spiritualism.' Contemporary religious people like the Amish see the world in the same factual way as secularists.
positions.implications: This suggests that phenomenological analyses of 'religion' often conflate fundamentally different phenomena: pre-rational animism vs. rational ethical-legal systems with spiritual elements.

positions.title: Spiritualism vs. Rationalism as Fundamental Orientations
positions.content: For the spiritualist, the world is a living subject and partner; for the rationalist, the world is dead matter existing only to be used as an object.
positions.context: Kuczynski outlines the fundamental contrast. For rationalists: the world is moving parts, nothing is sacred/profane, morality is engineering, the world is impersonal dead matter, life is an anomaly. For spiritualists: the world is a subject, not merely useful but a partner, teeming with life, morality is emotional/empathic, organisms are more basic than dead matter.
positions.implications: This contrast suggests fundamentally different ways of relating to existence, with the rationalist adopting an instrumental stance and the spiritualist maintaining an I-Thou relationship with reality.

positions.title: Humans Cannot Become Non-Spiritual
positions.content: Just as we cannot become asexual (per Freud), we cannot become non-spiritual; we can only mistakenly believe we are non-spiritual and thereby undermine our biological condition.
positions.context: Kuczynski interprets James, Otto, and Eliade as arguing that spiritualism is ineradicable from human nature. The problem is not lack of spiritualism but false belief in its absence. When we wrongly think we're non-spiritual—perhaps because we mistakenly see rationalism as rejecting rather than extending spiritualism—we adopt lifestyles that contravene our spiritual natures.
positions.implications: This suggests spiritualism is a fundamental aspect of human psychology that persists even when denied, similar to how sexual drives persist even when repressed.

positions.title: Rationalism as Extension of Spiritualism, Not Rejection
positions.content: Rationalism is a 'rarefied extension' of spiritualism, not a rejection of it; the error is seeing rationalism as anti-spiritual.
positions.context: Kuczynski's interpretation suggests that rationalism develops from and extends spiritualist impulses rather than opposing them. The problem arises when we erroneously conceive rationalism as rejecting spiritualism. This misunderstanding leads to lifestyles that contravene our spiritual natures.
positions.implications: This dissolves the apparent conflict between scientific rationalism and spiritual orientation, suggesting they're stages in a developmental process rather than opposed alternatives.

positions.title: Contemporary 'Spiritualism' is Actually Nihilism
positions.content: 21st-century self-described 'spiritual but not religious' people manifest nihilism and absence of genuine spiritualism, not its presence.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that modern 'spiritualism' (people who say they're 'spiritual but not religious') is in the same category as atheism—both manifest contemporary nihilism. Genuine spiritualism, as James, Otto, and Eliade describe it, involves seeing lightning as divine wrath naturally and immediately, not as a lifestyle choice or consumer identity. Contemporary spiritualism is self-conscious posturing rather than authentic spiritual experience.
positions.implications: This challenges the common view that 'spiritual but not religious' represents a viable third way, suggesting instead that it's merely another manifestation of modernity's spiritual emptiness.

positions.title: PWS Makes All True Propositions Necessary
positions.content: Possible World Semantics (PWS), properly understood, has the absurd consequence that all true propositions become necessarily true and all false propositions become necessarily false.
positions.context: Kuczynski's central thesis is that PWS collapses the distinction between contingent and necessary truth. If PWS is correct, then propositions like 'George W. Bush is U.S. president in 2006' become as necessary as '2+2=4,' and 'John Kerry is U.S. president in 2006' becomes as necessarily false as '2+2=5.' This is a reductio ad absurdum of PWS.
positions.implications: If valid, this argument undermines the entire PWS framework and all analyses based on it, requiring a fundamental reconception of modal semantics.

positions.title: PWS Requires Literal Interpretation of 'World'
positions.content: PWS is eviscerated unless the term 'world' is taken literally to mean concrete spatiotemporal realities, not abstract entities or linguistic constructions.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues (following Lewis 1986) that PWS only works if 'world' means genuine alternative universes, not sets of propositions, abstract states of affairs, or linguistic constructions. Any attempt to interpret 'worlds' as abstract entities reintroduces the very modal notions PWS attempts to analyze, creating vicious circularity.
positions.implications: This forces advocates of PWS to commit to the controversial metaphysical claim that infinitely many concrete alternative universes actually exist, which many find unacceptably extravagant.

positions.title: PWSE Creates Vicious Circularity via State Descriptions
positions.content: Attempts to identify worlds with 'maximal consistent sets of propositions' (state descriptions) involve vicious circularity because specifying which sets are consistent requires using modal concepts.
positions.context: Kuczynski shows that defining which sets of propositions qualify as 'possible worlds' requires independently determining which propositions are consistent with each other. But consistency is itself a modal notion: p is consistent with q iff it's possible for both to be true. Moreover, simple absence of explicit contradictions (p & ~p) is insufficient because many propositions are inconsistent without being negations (e.g., 'this is red' and 'this is green' about the same surface).
positions.implications: This shows that extensional approaches to modality (trying to analyze modal notions in non-modal terms using sets) systematically fail due to ineliminable circularity.

positions.title: Supervenience Creates Circularity for PWSE
positions.content: The phenomenon of supervenience creates an insurmountable circularity problem for attempts to identify worlds with sets of propositions.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that if a state description includes 'such-and-such micro-events are occurring,' it must also include 'so-and-so's heart is beating' (if the beating supervenes on those micro-events). But supervenience is standardly defined using worlds ('E supervenes on E* iff E occurs in any world where E* occurs') or necessity ('E supervenes on E* iff given E*, necessarily E'). Either definition makes it viciously circular to use supervenience to specify which sets of propositions count as worlds.
positions.implications: This shows that even sophisticated attempts to specify possible worlds using purely extensional criteria fail because they must covertly rely on modal notions.

positions.title: Non-Circular Supervenience Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
positions.content: If supervenience could be analyzed non-circularly without using modal concepts, then PWS would become unnecessary since we'd already have a non-modal analysis of modality.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents a dilemma: Either (1) defining supervenience uses modal concepts, in which case using it to specify worlds is circular, or (2) defining supervenience doesn't use modal concepts, in which case we've already analyzed modality non-modally and don't need PWS. This is a general pattern: any successful non-circular way of picking out the right sets of propositions would itself constitute an analysis of modality, making the appeal to worlds otiose.
positions.implications: This reveals a deep structural problem with PWS: either it's circular or it's unnecessary. Any move to escape circularity undermines the motivation for the theory.

positions.title: PWS Faces Unavoidable Dilemma - Circular or Superfluous
positions.content: PWS faces an inescapable dilemma: either it's viciously circular (using modal concepts to analyze modality) or it's superfluous (we already have a non-modal analysis making worlds unnecessary).
positions.context: Kuczynski generalizes the argument from MODAL-005. To avoid circularity, PWSE must find a non-modal way to identify which sets of propositions count as possible worlds. But possessing such a characterization would constitute a non-modal analysis of possibility (since we'd have a non-modal predicate satisfied by all and only possibly-true propositions). In that case, we no longer need to analyze modality in terms of worlds—we already have a direct analysis.
positions.implications: This suggests that PWS is fundamentally misguided as a project: modal concepts cannot be successfully reduced to or analyzed in terms of non-modal spatiotemporal concepts.

positions.title: Meta-Language Strategy Fails to Save PWS
positions.content: Relegating modal statements to a 'meta-language' does not eliminate vicious circularity problems for PWS.
positions.context: Advocates of PWSE try to avoid circularity by not allowing modal statements (which quantify over all worlds) to be members of worlds themselves—these go in the 'meta-language.' But Kuczynski shows this fails. Non-modal statements like 'Smith believes that possible worlds are not identical with members of U' can be members of worlds, yet these statements themselves quantify over the class of all worlds (U), creating the same circularity.
positions.implications: This closes off a major escape route for PWS, showing that standard logical techniques for avoiding circularity don't work in this context.

positions.title: Russell's Theory of Types Cannot Save PWS
positions.content: Attempts to avoid circularity by using Russell's Theory of Types (distinguishing 'orders' of propositions) fail in this context.
positions.context: One might try to resolve circularity by saying that when 'U' (the class of all worlds) appears in different contexts, it refers to different-order versions of the same set. Kuczynski shows this doesn't work because PWS requires that there be one determinate collection of all possible worlds. If we multiply this into different 'types,' we lose the determinacy required for modal analysis. Moreover, which 'level' of world contains ordinary propositions about Smith's beliefs becomes arbitrary.
positions.implications: This shows that sophisticated logical machinery developed to solve set-theoretic paradoxes cannot rescue PWS from its circularity problems.

positions.title: PWS Cannot Extensionalize Second-Order Properties
positions.content: PWS's identification of propositions with sets/functions forces it to deny that second-order properties (like necessity) are functions, which collapses the analysis of necessity.
positions.context: PWS identifies propositions with functions from worlds to truth-values (or with sets of worlds). If first-order properties were also functions, we'd falsely identify accidentally co-extensive properties. So PWS must deny that properties are functions. But then second-order properties (properties of properties, like necessity) also can't be functions. Yet PWS analyzes 'P is necessarily true' as P being assigned truth by function F (which assigns truth to all propositions true in every world). If necessity isn't a function, this analysis fails.
positions.implications: This shows that PWS's extensionalizing project is internally inconsistent: it requires treating some intensional entities (like necessity) as extensions while denying this for others (like properties).

positions.title: PWS Cannot Identify Intensional Entities with Extensions
positions.content: Propositions, properties, and other intensional entities cannot be identified with their extensions (sets, functions) without losing essential features like fine-grained individuation.
positions.context: PWS attempts to extensionalize intensional entities: propositions become sets of worlds, properties become functions or sets. But this fails to capture fine-grained distinctions. Necessarily equivalent propositions (like '2+2=4' and 'triangles have three sides') get identified despite being obviously distinct. Accidentally co-extensive properties (like 'renate' and 'cordate') get identified. The apparent elegance of extensionalization comes at the cost of fundamental distortions.
positions.implications: This suggests that intensional entities resist extensional analysis, requiring an intensional metaphysics and semantics.

positions.title: Inconsistency Without Explicit Contradiction
positions.content: Propositions can be mutually inconsistent without either being the negation of the other, undermining attempts to define consistency non-modally.
positions.context: Kuczynski points out (following later Wittgenstein) that 'x occurred at time t' is inconsistent with 'x occurred at time t*' (where t ≠ t*), yet neither is the negation of the other. Similarly, 'this surface is red' and 'this surface is green' are inconsistent without being negations. This means consistency cannot be understood purely as absence of (p & ~p) contradictions—it's an irreducibly modal notion involving what could jointly be true.
positions.implications: This shows that even basic logical notions like consistency are implicitly modal, making attempts to analyze modality in purely non-modal terms futile.

positions.title: Hintikka's Model Sets Presuppose Modality
positions.content: Hintikka's influential analysis of modality using model sets and state descriptions presupposes modal concepts and thus cannot provide a non-circular analysis of modality.
positions.context: Kuczynski examines Hintikka's system where necessity and possibility are defined relative to model systems (sets of state descriptions). A critical component is that some state descriptions are 'alternatives' to others (describing how the world might have gone differently). But the concept of being an 'alternative' is itself modal. Hintikka's system thus covertly uses modal notions to analyze modality.
positions.implications: Even sophisticated formal systems for modal logic, though valuable for many purposes, fail as analyses of the nature of modality itself.

positions.title: PWS Valuable as Statement, Not as Analysis
positions.content: Many contentions of PWS are correct and illuminating as statements about modality, but unacceptable as analyses of what modality consists in.
positions.context: Kuczynski emphasizes this crucial distinction throughout. It's truistic that 'P is possible iff P is true in some possible world.' As a statement, this is both correct and useful for systematizing modal reasoning. But as an analysis—an account of what possibility fundamentally is—it's circular (using 'possible world' to analyze 'possible'). PWS conflates statements with analyses.
positions.implications: This suggests we should value formal modal systems for their systematizing power while rejecting their pretensions to provide metaphysical analyses of modality's nature.

positions.title: Lewis's Counterpart Theory Faces Circularity
positions.content: David Lewis's counterpart theory, designed to solve problems for modal realism, either involves vicious circularity or makes modal claims depend on arbitrary resemblance relations.
positions.context: Lewis proposes that modal claims about an individual (like 'Socrates might have been a carpenter') should be understood in terms of counterparts—individuals in other worlds resembling Socrates. But: (1) If resemblance means 'sharing essential properties,' this is circular since essentiality is modal. (2) If resemblance means maximum similarity (without modal content), modal truths become arbitrary (which things happen to resemble Socrates most). (3) If counterpart is primitive, the connection to our modal intuitions is severed.
positions.implications: This suggests that even sophisticated versions of modal realism face deep problems connecting their technical apparatus to ordinary modal concepts.

positions.title: Essentiality of Origins Creates Problem for Counterpart Theory
positions.content: The plausible doctrine that origins are essential to individuals creates circularity for counterpart theory because identifying counterparts requires knowing essential properties, but identifying essential properties requires the counterpart relation.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents a vicious circle: If Socrates essentially has parents A and B, then Socrates' counterpart in another world must have as parents the counterparts of A and B. But who are A's and B's counterparts? Those whose parents are the counterparts of A's and B's parents. This regresses infinitely or circles viciously. The concept of counterpart is understood via essence (same origins), and essence is understood via counterpart.
positions.implications: This shows that combining counterpart theory with plausible essentialist doctrines (like Kripke's essentiality of origins) leads to incoherence.

positions.title: Counterpart as Primitive Makes Modal Claims Unintuitive
positions.content: If the counterpart relation is taken as primitive (not analyzable in terms of resemblance or essence), then modal claims become detached from our intuitions because they depend on brute facts about trans-world relations.
positions.context: Lewis acknowledges that one option is to treat 'x is Socrates' counterpart in W' as a primitive, unanalyzable fact. But then, as Lewis admits, counterpart theory loses its intuitive basis. If someone in another world whose life bears no resemblance to mine is nevertheless my 'counterpart,' it's unclear why that person's fortunes should validate modal claims about me.
positions.implications: This reveals a fundamental tension in modal realism: technical adequacy purchased at the cost of intuitive connection to ordinary modal thinking.

positions.title: Properties Have Counterfactual Content
positions.content: Following C.I. Lewis, practically all property attributions to spatiotemporal objects have counterfactual content, which creates deep problems for any attempt to analyze counterfactuals non-circularly.
positions.context: C.I. Lewis showed that classifying something as 'wet,' 'cold,' or 'solid' involves claims about its behavior under counterfactual circumstances (what would happen if you touched it, heated it, etc.). Since almost all properties used to describe spatiotemporal objects have this structure, and since counterpart theory needs to individuate things by their properties without circularity, counterpart theory faces insurmountable circularity problems.
positions.implications: This suggests that attempts to analyze modal and counterfactual notions in non-modal terms face a fundamental obstacle: the very concepts used in the analysis (properties of objects) are themselves modal.

positions.title: 'Innocent' Essential Property Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
positions.content: If there were a non-circular way of characterizing which properties are essential to individuals, counterpart theory would become unnecessary for modal analysis.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents another dilemma: If we could characterize essential properties without using modal concepts (an 'innocent' characterization), we wouldn't need worlds or counterparts to explicate modality—we'd already have a non-modal analysis. If we can't provide such a characterization, then using essence to define counterparts involves circularity. Either way, counterpart theory fails to achieve its goals.
positions.implications: This is another instance of the general pattern: PWS frameworks are either circular or unnecessary for modal analysis.

positions.title: Modal Realism Requires Retrograde Space-Time Conceptions
positions.content: David Lewis's PWS-based analysis of counterfactuals succeeds only if we accept philosophically retrograde conceptions of space and time.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's analysis requires treating spatial and temporal relations as fundamentally different from causal relations, which goes against modern physics and philosophy of science. The analysis also requires absolute space and time rather than relativistic space-time, making it scientifically dated.
positions.implications: This suggests that even if PWS worked formally, it would be unacceptable because it commits us to outdated metaphysical views about space and time.

positions.title: Counterfactuals and Causation Cannot Be Separated
positions.content: Counterfactual conditionals cannot be analyzed independently of causation; attempts to analyze causation in terms of counterfactuals (or vice versa) are circular.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's attempt to analyze counterfactuals in terms of similarity of worlds faces problems when trying to specify the relevant similarity metric. Causal structure seems essential to determining which worlds are 'closer,' but causation itself is often analyzed in terms of counterfactuals, creating circularity.
positions.implications: This suggests that counterfactuals and causation are conceptually interdependent, resisting reduction to more basic non-modal, non-causal notions.

positions.title: Similarity Metrics for Worlds Are Arbitrary Without Causation
positions.content: Without invoking causal structure, any similarity metric used to compare possible worlds for counterfactual analysis becomes arbitrary and unintuitive.
positions.context: Lewis's counterfactual analysis says 'If P had been true, Q would have been true' means 'In the closest possible world where P is true, Q is true.' But which worlds count as 'closest'? Without building in causal structure, similarity judgments become arbitrary. But if we build in causation, we face circularity since causation itself is often analyzed counterfactually.
positions.implications: This reveals that PWS analyses of counterfactuals cannot avoid either arbitrariness or circularity in specifying the crucial similarity ordering.

positions.title: Modal Questions About Worlds Are Substantive
positions.content: Given truisms about spatiotemporal existence, it's a substantive modal question whether the worlds needed for PWS are even possible—a question PWS cannot answer without circularity.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that we should ask: Are worlds containing light but not electromagnetic radiation possible? Are worlds with different natural laws possible? PWS claims these questions should be answered by checking whether such worlds are members of the space of possible worlds. But that's circular—we need to know if such worlds are possible to know if they're in the space of possible worlds. The modal status of alternative worlds must be resolved within some other modal framework.
positions.implications: This shows that PWS is 'parasitic on some more fundamental understanding of modality'—it presupposes rather than analyzes modal concepts.

positions.title: Modality as Internal Structural Properties
positions.content: A proposition's being necessarily true consists in its having certain internal structural properties; truth in all possible worlds is merely a symptom, not the essence, of necessity.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues (following Bealer 1998 and in his own work) that we know 'triangles have three sides' is necessary by examining how the proposition's components relate to each other—its internal structure. Being true in all worlds is a consequence of this internal structure, not what necessity consists in. This inverts PWS: worlds are useful for systematizing modal facts, but modality is more basic than worlds.
positions.implications: This suggests a return to a more traditional rationalist conception where necessity is grounded in conceptual/structural features rather than in modal space.

positions.title: Lewis's Recombination Principle Supports Structural View
positions.content: David Lewis's own account of modal epistemology (his 'principle of recombination') ironically supports the view that modality consists in structural properties rather than truth across worlds.
positions.context: Lewis says we discover whether P is necessary by employing a 'principle of recombination'—checking whether P's constituents are combined in certain ways. But Kuczynski points out that this means we know P's modal status by examining P's internal structure, and we can do this without 'leaving this world.' If P's structure is sufficient for knowing its modal status, why not analyze necessity in terms of that structure rather than in terms of other worlds?
positions.implications: This suggests that Lewis's own epistemology of modality undermines his metaphysics of modality, pointing toward a structural rather than world-based analysis.

positions.title: PWS Creates Set-Theoretic Paradoxes
positions.content: Identifying worlds with sets of propositions creates vicious circle problems analogous to classical set-theoretic paradoxes.
positions.context: When worlds are sets of propositions, and some propositions quantify over or refer to 'all worlds,' we get a member of a member of the set of all worlds quantifying over that very set. This is structurally similar to Russell's paradox and other set-theoretic contradictions involving self-reference.
positions.implications: This suggests that PWS faces not just technical difficulties but fundamental logical-mathematical problems that may be insurmountable.

positions.title: Propositions Not Identifiable with Sets of Worlds
positions.content: Propositions cannot be identified with sets of possible worlds because this fails to distinguish necessarily equivalent but distinct propositions.
positions.context: PWS (contention 3) says a proposition is the set of worlds where it's true. But then '2+2=4' and 'triangles have three sides' are the same proposition (both true in all worlds). This is clearly wrong—they're distinct propositions. PWS might respond that propositions have 'structure,' but then they're no longer sets of worlds but structured entities, undermining the extensionalizing project.
positions.implications: This shows that the extensionalizing ambitions of PWS fail for one of its core theses—propositions must be treated as structured intensional entities.

positions.title: Propositions Require Internal Structure
positions.content: Propositions must be understood as having internal structure (being built from concepts in particular arrangements) rather than as unstructured sets or functions.
positions.context: Because necessarily equivalent propositions are distinct (2+2=4 ≠ triangles have three sides), and because we need to explain how we know modal facts by examining propositions' internal features, propositions must be structured. They're not mere sets of worlds or truth-functions, but complex entities built from concepts in specific configurations.
positions.implications: This requires developing an account of propositions as structured complex entities, perhaps along lines suggested by Russell's theory of propositions or more recent structured proposition theories.

positions.title: Some Semantic Concepts Must Be Primitive
positions.content: Attempts to analyze all semantic/modal concepts in terms of other concepts fail; some concepts (like consistency, possibility, or semantic consequence) must be taken as primitive.
positions.context: Kuczynski's arguments repeatedly show that attempts to reduce modal concepts to non-modal ones, or semantic concepts to set-theoretic ones, fail due to circularity or triviality. This suggests that semantic and modal concepts form a network of interdependencies where some must be taken as unanalyzed primitives, understood through their role in the system rather than via reduction.
positions.implications: This challenges reductionist programs in philosophy of language and suggests a more holistic approach where concepts are understood through their interrelations rather than foundational definitions.

positions.title: Pre-Civilizational Perception as Direct and Natural
positions.content: Pre-civilizational humans perceived agency and meaning in natural phenomena (lightning as divine wrath) directly and naturally, not through cultural interpretation or belief.
positions.context: Kuczynski contrasts genuine pre-civilizational spiritualism with contemporary religious belief. Stone age tribesmen saw lightning as divine wrath because 'this is how he naturally sees the world, not because he has been taught that this is how he should see the world.' This is direct perception, not interpreted belief. Modern religious people (like the Amish) 'see the world in the same way' as seculars—they see rocks as rocks, not as beating hearts.
positions.implications: This suggests fundamental differences in perceptual experience across historical-cultural contexts, challenging universalist accounts of perception.

positions.title: Modal Realism's Ontological Extravagance
positions.content: Modal realism requires accepting the concrete existence of infinitely many alternative universes, an ontological commitment many philosophers find unacceptably extravagant.
positions.context: If PWS requires literal worlds (MODAL-002), then we must believe that there actually exist concrete universes where Napoleon won at Waterloo, where dinosaurs still exist, where physics is different, etc. This multiplies entities beyond what most philosophers find acceptable (violating Occam's Razor dramatically).
positions.implications: This practical consequence of literal PWS leads many philosophers to seek alternative accounts of modality even if they can't identify specific logical flaws in modal realism.

positions.title: Essentialism and Modal Knowledge
positions.content: The doctrine that objects have essential properties (properties they must have to exist) creates special problems for modal analysis but may be unavoidable.
positions.context: Kuczynski discusses the plausible view (due to Kripke) that origins are essential: Socrates couldn't have had different parents. This essentialist doctrine is intuitive but creates problems for counterpart theory. More generally, essentialism suggests that modal facts about individuals depend on which of their properties are essential vs. accidental, requiring some account of this distinction.
positions.implications: This suggests that adequate modal metaphysics must incorporate essentialism but needs to explain essential properties without circular appeal to modal concepts.

positions.title: Space-Time Structure and Modality
positions.content: Questions about the structure of space-time (whether it's absolute or relational, whether space and time are unified) have implications for modal metaphysics.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's counterfactual analysis requires specific, controversial assumptions about space-time structure. If space-time is relativistic rather than Newtonian, if spatial relations are not fundamentally different from causal relations, then Lewis's analysis fails. This shows that modal metaphysics can't be developed independently of philosophy of physics.
positions.implications: This suggests that modal metaphysics must be continuous with scientific metaphysics, incorporating results from fundamental physics.

positions.title: Brain Centers for Militant Atheism and Fundamentalism Are Identical
positions.content: The brain structures that mediate militant atheism are the same as those mediating religious fundamentalism.
positions.context: Kuczynski claims that contemporary militant atheists and religious fundamentalists, despite having opposite beliefs, use the same neural circuitry. Both represent dogmatic, emotionally-driven responses rather than reasoned positions. This neurological fact supports the view that much contemporary 'rationalism' and 'irrationalism' are psychologically equivalent.
positions.implications: This suggests that the form of belief (dogmatic, tribal, emotional) may be more psychologically fundamental than its content (religious vs. secular).

positions.title: Denying Spiritualism Causes Psychological Morbidity
positions.content: According to James, Otto, and Eliade, genuinely lacking belief in transcendence (not merely lacking explicit religion) leads to various forms of psychological disorder.
positions.context: These thinkers hold that when people truly don't believe 'this world is not all there is,' they suffer psychological damage. Healthy atheists/agnostics actually hold variants of this transcendent view without recognizing it. The problem is not lacking institutional religion but lacking a sense of meaning beyond the mundane, which causes 'psychological morbidity.'
positions.implications: This suggests that certain forms of meaning-making or transcendent orientation are psychologically necessary, independent of explicit religious belief.

positions.title: Historical Variation in Fundamental Psychology
positions.content: Basic psychological structures (like perception and meaning-making) vary fundamentally across historical and cultural contexts, challenging universalist psychology.
positions.context: Kuczynski's account implies that pre-civilizational humans had fundamentally different perceptual and cognitive experiences from modern humans. They directly perceived agency in nature; we don't. This isn't just different beliefs with the same experiences—it's different experiences. This suggests that historical and cultural contexts shape basic psychology, not just explicit beliefs.
positions.implications: This challenges both evolutionary psychology (which emphasizes universal mechanisms) and phenomenology (which often treats experience structures as universal), suggesting deeper historical variation.

positions.title: Material Conditions Shape Consciousness
positions.content: Material developments (like writing and economic organization) fundamentally shape modes of consciousness, including temporal awareness and rationality.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that writing creates rationalism, that economies of scale cause time-linearization, and that material social conditions determine basic categories of thought. This represents a materialist theory of consciousness where cognitive structures emerge from and reflect social-material conditions.
positions.implications: This suggests a broadly Marxist or materialist approach to consciousness and epistemology, where thought structures are not timeless but products of specific historical-material conditions.

positions.title: Natural Laws and Modal Space
positions.content: The relationship between natural laws and what's metaphysically possible is a substantive question that PWS presupposes rather than answers.
positions.context: Kuczynski asks: Are worlds with different laws of nature possible? Are worlds with light but not EM radiation possible? PWS should answer these by checking if such worlds are in modal space. But to construct modal space, we need to know which worlds are possible, which requires knowing if violations of natural law are possible. This is a substantive scientific-metaphysical question, not answerable within PWS.
positions.implications: This suggests that modal metaphysics cannot be developed a priori but must engage with philosophy of science and actual scientific theories about laws of nature.

positions.title: Levels of Analysis in Studying Phenomena
positions.content: Phenomena like religion admit of both reductive (causal-explanatory) and non-reductive (phenomenological-essential) analysis, both of which may provide genuine truths.
positions.context: Following James, Kuczynski recognizes that religion can be studied scientifically (explaining its causes and functions) and phenomenologically (describing its essential features). These are complementary rather than competing approaches. The reductive level explains why religion exists; the non-reductive level describes what it is. Both levels are legitimate and necessary.
positions.implications: This supports methodological pluralism in human sciences, rejecting both naive reductionism and anti-naturalist obscurantism.

positions.title: Statement vs. Analysis in Philosophy
positions.content: Many philosophical claims are valuable as true statements while failing as analyses; confusing these roles leads to philosophical errors.
positions.context: Kuczynski emphasizes throughout that 'P is possible iff P is true in some possible world' is a correct statement—even a truism—but fails as an analysis because it's circular. Good systematization (organizing our modal thinking using possible worlds) doesn't imply good analysis (explaining what possibility consists in). Much of modal logic succeeds as systematization while failing as metaphysical analysis.
positions.implications: This methodological distinction helps resolve debates in metaphysics and semantics by clarifying what different theoretical frameworks accomplish and where their limits lie.

positions.title: Limits of Conceptual Analysis
positions.content: Attempts to analyze all concepts in terms of more basic ones eventually fail; some concepts must be accepted as primitive and understood through their systematic interrelations.
positions.context: Kuczynski's arguments show that modal concepts can't be reduced to non-modal ones, that consistency presupposes modality, that semantic concepts can't be fully extensionalized. This suggests that the project of reductive conceptual analysis has limits. Some concepts are primitive, understood through their role in a system of concepts rather than through definition in more basic terms.
positions.implications: This suggests moving away from foundationalist approaches to concepts toward more holistic accounts where meaning is determined by systematic role rather than reductive definition.

positions.title: Theoretical Virtues and Theory Choice
positions.content: When choosing between theories, factors like ontological parsimony, intuitive plausibility, and coherence with science matter alongside formal adequacy.
positions.context: Kuczynski's critique of PWS goes beyond formal logical problems to include considerations of ontological extravagance (too many entities), counter-intuitiveness (modal realism violates common sense), and scientific adequacy (retrograde space-time conceptions). This implies that theory choice involves weighing multiple virtues, not just logical consistency.
positions.implications: This supports a pluralistic account of theoretical rationality where various considerations must be balanced rather than a single criterion (like logical consistency or empirical adequacy) being decisive.

positions.title: Role of Intuition in Modal Knowledge
positions.content: Modal intuitions (about what's possible/necessary) play a crucial but problematic role in modal epistemology and cannot be simply dismissed.
positions.context: Kuczynski appeals to intuitions about modal claims throughout. When counterpart theory makes modal truths depend on arbitrary facts, this counts as a problem because it's counterintuitive. But how should intuitions inform theory? If theories can't violate intuitions, science would be impossible. Yet theories completely detached from intuitions lose connection to what they're theorizing about.
positions.implications: This raises deep questions about the role of intuition in philosophy—how much revisionism is acceptable? When do counterintuitive consequences refute a theory vs. revealing surprising truths?

positions.title: Arbitrariness as Theoretical Vice
positions.content: When theoretical claims depend on arbitrary choices (with no principled basis), this is a serious theoretical defect even if the theory is formally consistent.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that if which modal claims are true depends on arbitrary choices (like which similarity metric we use for comparing worlds, or which things we stipulate as counterparts), the theory fails even if it's formally adequate. Arbitrariness indicates that the theory isn't tracking objective features of reality but rather reflects our conventional choices.
positions.implications: This suggests that good theories must avoid arbitrary elements, providing principled bases for their claims—a constraint beyond mere consistency or empirical adequacy.

positions.title: Modal Knowledge via Structural Analysis
positions.content: We know modal truths by examining the internal structure of propositions—how their constituent concepts are arranged and related—not by surveying alternative worlds.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that we know 'triangles have three sides' is necessary by analyzing the proposition itself—examining how the concepts 'triangle,' 'three,' and 'side' relate. We don't need to check all possible worlds. This suggests a rationalist epistemology where modal knowledge comes from conceptual analysis rather than empirical survey or stipulation.
positions.implications: This supports a return to rationalist epistemology for modal knowledge, contra empiricist approaches and contra the suggestion that modal knowledge requires metaphysically extravagant commitments.

positions.title: Conceptual Understanding as Basic
positions.content: Some forms of understanding (like grasping concepts and their relations) are basic and cannot be further analyzed or reduced to other cognitive processes.
positions.context: The structural account of modality and modal knowledge presupposes that we can grasp concepts and understand their internal relations. This understanding appears to be primitive—not analyzable in terms of more basic cognitive or computational processes. It's the foundation of rational thought rather than something requiring deeper explanation.
positions.implications: This challenges computational and empiricist theories of mind that try to explain all cognition in terms of more basic (computational, associative, sensory) processes, suggesting instead that conceptual understanding is sui generis.

positions.title: Tractatus vs. Later Wittgenstein on Contradiction
positions.content: Wittgenstein's early view (Tractatus) that all inconsistency reduces to explicit contradiction was questioned in his later work, which recognized irreducible forms of inconsistency.
positions.context: Kuczynski cites Wittgenstein's development. The Tractatus held that all inconsistency could be understood as presence of (p & ~p). But in Philosophical Remarks, Wittgenstein questioned this, noting that 'this is red' and 'this is green' (about the same surface) are inconsistent without either being the negation of the other. This recognition supports Kuczynski's critique of attempts to define consistency non-modally.
positions.implications: This shows that even a philosopher initially committed to a simple logical picture of inconsistency came to recognize its irreducible complexity, supporting Kuczynski's anti-reductionist arguments.

positions.title: Set-Theoretic Foundations and Paradoxes
positions.content: Attempts to use set theory as a foundation for semantics and modal metaphysics face fundamental paradoxes related to self-reference and circularity.
positions.context: Kuczynski shows that when worlds are identified with sets, standard set-theoretic paradoxes emerge in new forms. Members of worlds quantify over the space of all worlds, creating vicious circles. Standard solutions (like Russell's Theory of Types) don't work in this context because modal analysis requires a determinate, unified space of worlds rather than a hierarchy of types.
positions.implications: This suggests that set theory, despite its value in mathematics, may not provide an appropriate foundation for modal metaphysics and semantics, which require different conceptual resources.

positions.title: Conceptual Thought Cannot Be Fully Extensionalized
positions.content: The attempt to reduce intensional mental states and contents to extensional structures (sets, functions, physical states) systematically fails.
positions.context: PWS's extensionalizing project—treating propositions as sets of worlds, properties as functions—fails because it can't preserve the fine-grained distinctions essential to thought and meaning. Necessarily equivalent propositions that are obviously distinct get identified. This suggests that mental content has an irreducible intensional structure that resists extensional analysis.
positions.implications: This supports intentionalist theories in philosophy of mind and argues against computational/functional theories that try to identify mental states with formal/physical structures.
